metadata.case_name: Town Municipal Council, Athani v. Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Hubli & Ors.

facts.text: Four applications under section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act filed in Labour Court, Hubli by workmen of Town Municipal Council, Athani.

Application LCH No. 139 of 1965 filed by eleven workmen on 28th July 1965 seeking computation of claim for overtime work from 1st April 1955 to 31st December 1957 and work on weekly off-days from 1st April 1955 to 31st December 1960. Total claim Rs. 62,420.82P.

Application LCH No. 138 of 1965 presented by 50 workmen on 23rd July 1965 for washing allowance Rs. 36 each from 1st January 1964 to 30th June 1965 and cost of uniform Rs. 40 each from 1st January 1964 to 30th June 1965 for 18 workmen.
Application LCH No. 101 of 1965 filed by one workman on 19th April 1965 claiming Rs. 8,910.72P for overtime and compensation for weekly off days.
Application LCH No. 140 of 1965 filed on 26th July 1965 by 14 workmen claiming Rs. 17,302.60P for work on weekly off-days from 1st December 1960 to 30th June 1965.
Labour Court, Hubli entertained applications, computed amounts due and directed appellant to pay.
Appellant filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in Mysore High Court: WP 741/1966 (vs LCH 139/65), 973/1966 (vs 138/65), 974/1966 (vs 101/65), 975/1966 (vs 140/65).
Mysore High Court dismissed writ petitions by common order dated 25th August 1967.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court: Civil Appeals Nos. 170 to 173 of 1968.
Objection to jurisdiction raised before Labour Court and High Court on ground of Minimum Wages Act s.20(1).
In CA 171/1968 (from WP 973/66 re LCH 138/65), appellant conceded point not pressable as claims for washing allowance and uniform not governed by Minimum Wages Act.
New point on whether applications covered by s.33C(2) sought to be raised first time in SC but permission refused.
New point on limitation under Art.137 Limitation Act 1963 permitted as raised by application.

legal_issues.text: Whether jurisdiction of Labour Court under s.33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act barred by s.20(1) of Minimum Wages Act.
Whether applications under s.33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act before Labour Court governed by 3-year limitation under Art.137 of Limitation Act 1963.

petitioner_arguments.text: Claims could have been made under s.20(1) Minimum Wages Act, which is self-contained, excluding jurisdiction of Labour Court under general Industrial Disputes Act; claims time-barred under that section.
Applications time-barred under Art.137 Limitation Act 1963.

respondent_arguments.text: Jurisdiction not excluded; claims not relatable to rates under Minimum Wages Act but to computation of benefits at agreed rates.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s.33C(2); Minimum Wages Act s.20(1)

court_reasoning.text: Claims under s.33C(2) not cognizable under s.20(1) Minimum Wages Act as no dispute on rates; s.20(1) for ensuring compliance with fixed rates, not enforcement where rates undisputed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minimum Wages Act concerned with fixing rates, not enforcement of payments where no rate dispute.

court_reasoning.text: No dispute on rates in applications or pleadings; only whether rates fixed at all, not making it rate dispute.
Art.137 Limitation Act 1963 applies only to applications to courts governed by CPC/CrPC, not to Labour Court which is quasi-judicial tribunal not governed by those codes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ejusdem generis with earlier articles; changes in 1963 Act do not extend to non-court bodies.

court_reasoning.text: Overrules Manager Mills P.K. Porwal v. Labour Court Nagpur as ignoring that Labour Court not a court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Court applications not governed by Limitation Act Art.137.

holdings.text: Labour Court jurisdiction under s.33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act not barred by Minimum Wages Act s.20(1) where no rate dispute.
Art.137 Limitation Act 1963 does not apply to applications under s.33C(2) before Labour Court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sha Mulchand Co. Ltd. In Liquidation v. Jawahar Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.181 Limitation Act 1908 applies only to CPC applications; ejusdem generis.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bombay Gas Co. Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.181 does not apply to s.33C(2) applications.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manager, Mills P.K. Porwal v. The Labour Court at Nagpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Art.137 applies to s.33C(2); disagreed as Labour Court not court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hansraj Gupta v. Official Liquidators, Dehra Dun Mussoorie Electric Tramway Co. Ltd.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs applications for computation of benefits; Labour Court jurisdiction not excluded.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: For claims re rates fixed under Act; not for undisputed rate enforcement.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: 3-year limit for court applications only, not Labour Court.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Predecessor; interpreted ejusdem generis for CPC applications.

statutes_cited.name: Payment of Wages Act, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Alternative remedy for payment enforcement where rates undisputed.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs courts to which Limitation Act articles apply.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Some applications under it included in Limitation Schedule.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs, upholding Labour Court orders and High Court dismissal; held no bar by Minimum Wages Act and no applicability of Limitation Act Art.137 to s.33C(2) applications before Labour Court.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; Labour Court directions to pay claims upheld.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. One hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "Art. 137 of the schedule to the Limitation Act, 1963 does not apply to applications under s.33C(2) of the Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the claims made by the workmen in the applications under S.33C(2) of the Act could not have been made before the Labour Court under s.20(1) of the Minimum Wages Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "This long catena of decisions may well be said to have, as it were, added the words 'under the Code' in the first column of that article."
key_quotes.speaker: court
